speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At the Federal Reserve, we are strongly committed to achieving the monetary policy goals that Congress has given us: maximum employment and price stability.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Today, the Federal Open Market Committee kept interest rates near zero and maintained our current pace of asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These measures, along with our strong guidance on interest rates and on our balance sheet, will ensure that monetary policy will continue to support the economy until the recovery is complete.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Progress on vaccinations and unprecedented fiscal policy actions are also providing strong support to the recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Indicators of economic activity and employment have continued to strengthen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Real GDP rose at a robust 6.4 percent pace in the first half of the year, and growth is widely expected to continue at a strong pace in the second half.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The sectors most adversely affected by the pandemic have improved in recent months, but the rise in COVID-19 cases has slowed their recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Household spending rose at an especially rapid pace over the first half of the year but flattened out in July and August as spending softened in COVID-sensitive sectors, such as travel and restaurants.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Additionally, in some industries, near-term supply constraints are restraining activity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These constraints are particularly acute in the motor vehicle industry, where the worldwide shortage of semiconductors has sharply curtailed production.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Partly reflecting the effects of the virus and supply constraints, forecasts from FOMC participants for economic growth this year have been revised somewhat lower since our June Summary of Economic Projections, but participants still foresee rapid growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As with overall economic activity, conditions in the labor market have continued to improve.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Demand for labor is very strong, and job gains averaged 750,000 per month over the past three months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In August, however, job gains slowed markedly, with the slowdown concentrated in sectors most sensitive to the pandemic, including leisure and hospitality.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The unemployment rate was 5.2 percent in August, and this figure understates the shortfall in employment, particularly as participation in the labor market has not moved up from the low rates that have prevailed for most of the past year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Factors related to the pandemic, such as caregiving needs and ongoing fears of the virus, appear to be weighing on employment growth.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These factors should diminish with progress on containing the virus, leading to more rapid gains in employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Looking ahead, FOMC participants project the labor market to continue to improve, with the median projection for the unemployment rate standing at 4.8 percent at the end of this year and 3.5 percent in 2023 and ’24.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economic downturn has not fallen equally on all Americans, and those least able to shoulder the burden have been hardest hit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In particular, despite progress, joblessness continues to fall disproportionately on lower-wage workers in the service sector and on African Americans and Hispanics.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation is elevated and will likely remain so in coming months before moderating.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As the economy continues to reopen and spending rebounds, we are seeing upward pressure on prices, particularly because supply bottlenecks in some sectors have limited how quickly production can respond in the near term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These bottleneck effects have been larger and longer lasting than anticipated, leading to upward revisions to participants’ inflation projections for this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While these supply effects are prominent for now, they will abate, and as they do, inflation September 22, 2021 is expected to drop back toward our longer-run goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The median inflation projection from Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL FOMC participants falls from 4.2 percent this year to 2.2 percent next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The process of reopening the economy is unprecedented, as was the shutdown at the onset of the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As the reopening continues, bottlenecks, hiring difficulties, and other constraints could again prove to be greater and longer lasting than anticipated, posing upside risks to inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our framework for monetary policy emphasizes the importance of having well-anchored inflation expectations, both to foster price stability and to enhance our ability to promote our broad-based and inclusive maximum-employment goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Indicators of longer-term inflation expectations appear broadly consistent with our longer-run inflation goal of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If sustained higher inflation were to become a serious concern, we would certainly respond and use our tools to assure that inflation runs at levels that are consistent with our goal.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The path of the economy continues to depend on the course of the virus, and risks to the economic outlook remain.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Delta variant has led to significant increases in COVID-19 cases, resulting in significant hardship and loss and slowing the economic recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Continued progress on vaccinations would help contain the virus and support a return to more normal economic conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Fed’s policy actions have been guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people, along with our responsibilities to promote the stability of the financial system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our asset purchases have been a critical tool.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They helped preserve financial stability and market functioning early in the pandemic and since then have helped foster accommodative financial conditions to support the economy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: At our meeting that concluded earlier today, the Committee continued to discuss the progress made toward our goals since the Committee adopted its asset purchase guidance last September 22, 2021 December.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Since then, the economy has made progress toward these goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If progress Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL continues broadly as expected, the Committee judges that a moderation in the pace of asset purchases may soon be warranted.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also discussed the appropriate pace of tapering asset purchases once economic conditions satisfy the criterion laid out in the Committee’s guidance.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: While no decisions were made, participants generally view that, so long as the recovery remains on track, a gradual tapering process that concludes around the middle of next year is likely to be appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Even after our balance sheet stops expanding, our elevated holdings of longer-term securities will continue to support accommodative financial conditions.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The timing and pace of the coming reduction in asset purchases will not be intended to carry a direct signal regarding the timing of interest rate liftoff, for which we have articulated a different and substantially more stringent test.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We continue to expect that it will be appropriate to maintain the current 0 to ¼ percent target range for the federal funds rate until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with the Committee’s assessment of maximum employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Half of FOMC participants forecast that these favorable economic conditions will be fulfilled by the end of next year; as a result, the median projection for the appropriate level of the federal funds rate lies slightly above the effective lower bound in 2022.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Participants generally expect a gradual pace of policy firming that would leave the level of the federal funds rate below estimates of its longer-run level through 2024.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, these projections do not represent a Committee decision or plan, and no one knows with any certainty where the economy will be a year or more from now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: More important than any forecast is the September 22, 2021 fact that policy will remain accommodative until we have achieved our maximum-employment Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL and price-stability goals.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: To conclude, we understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We at the Fed will do everything we can to support the economy for as long as it takes to complete the recovery.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you, and I look forward to your questions.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: We’ll go first to Rachel Siegel.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: Thank you, Michelle.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: And thank you, Chair Powell, for taking our questions.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: When it comes to the taper and, eventually, to any rate increases, I’m wondering if you can walk us through what “substantial further progress” looks like, given the latest batch of projections that have PCE inflation coming in a little higher than the June projection, the unemployment rate also being higher than June, as well as the change to GDP lower than June.

speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL
sentence: If you could help us make sense of all those things as you sort through what “substantial further progress” looks like, that would be great.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the test for beginning our taper is that we’ve achieved substantial further progress toward our goals of [2 percent] inflation and maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And for inflation, we appear to have achieved more than significant progress—substantial further progress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that part of the test is achieved, in my view and in the view of many others.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So the question is really on the maximum-employment test.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So if you look at a good number of indicators, you will see that, since last December, when we articulated the test, and the readings today, in many cases more than half of the distance, for example, between the unemployment rate in December of 2020 and typical estimates of the natural rate—50 or 60 percent of that road has been traveled.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that could be substantial further progress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many on the Committee feel that the “substantial further progress” test for employment has been met.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Others feel that it’s close, but they want to see a little more progress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a range of perspectives.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I guess my own view would be that the test—the “substantial further progress” test for employment is all but met.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so, once we’ve met those two tests, once the Committee decides that they’ve met [them]—and that could come as soon as the next meeting; that’s the purpose of that language, is to put notice out that that could come as soon as the next meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The Committee will consider that test, and we’ll also look at the broader environment at that time and make a decision whether to taper.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: We’ll go to Howard Schneider.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Thanks, Chair Powell.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: Thanks, Michelle.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: So, looking at the SEPs, we got now basically four years of inflation above target, and policy never gets to the long-run rate.

speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER
sentence: I’m wondering if you could address that from two perspectives: one, within the new framework that the Fed adopted last year and, second, from the perspective of the average household that’s now being asked to pay higher prices and increasingly higher prices for four years running when, for some this year, real wages have actually gone down.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, as you can see, the inflation forecasts have moved up a bit in the outyears.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s really, I think, a reflection of—and they’ve moved up significantly for this year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s, I think, a reflection of the fact that the bottlenecks and shortages that are being—that we’re seeing in the economy have really not begun to abate in a meaningful way yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So those seem to be going to be with us at least for a few more months and perhaps into next year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that suggests that inflation’s going to be higher this year, and a number—I guess the inflation rates for next year and 2023 were also marked up, but just by a couple of tenths.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Why—those are very modest overshoots.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re looking at 2.2 and 2.1, you know, two years September 22, 2021 and three years out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: These are very, very—I don’t think that households are going to, you know, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL notice a couple of tenths of an overshoot.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That just happens to be people’s forecasts.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, we want to foster a strong labor market, and we want to foster inflation averaging 2 percent over time, and I think we’re very much on track to achieve those things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the framework, I see this as very consistent with the framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want inflation expectations to be anchored at around 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We want, we’re—that’s really the ultimate test of whether we’re getting this done under the framework.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we do want inflation to run moderately above 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I wouldn’t put too much on a couple of tenths over 2 percent in 2023 and ’24—one-tenth in ’24.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you’re right, those are the numbers.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Let’s go to Colby Smith.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: Chair Powell—thank you, Michelle.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: Chair Powell, you mentioned ongoing discussions about the tapering timeline, and I’m wondering what the contours of that debate have been.

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: For those that want to move a bit more quickly, is it about maintaining optionality for a 2022 interest rate increase?

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: Or is it about financial stability risks?

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: Or concerns about the efficacy of asset purchases at a time when we have supply constraints?

speaker: COLBY SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So let me say that there’s very broad support on the Committee for this plan, both as to the timing and as to the pace of the taper.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So this was a unanimous vote today, and I’d say quite broad support for this approach.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re correct that there are some who would prefer to have gone sooner, and they’ve made their arguments publicly.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For some of them, it’s a financial stability concern.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And for others, it’s other concerns.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They can make their own arguments.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is an approach that the Committee will broadly support, and it will put us having completed our taper sometime around the middle of next year, which seems appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the asset purchases, as I mentioned, were very, very important at the—in the early stages of the crisis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They were essential in restoring market function in the Treasury and other markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Then, as the recovery got going, they supported aggregate demand, as they will do.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And now we’re in a situation where they still have a use, but it’s time for us to begin to taper them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Their usefulness is much less as a tool than it was at the very beginning.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, of course, this leaves the whole question of rate increases ahead, which is really where the framework—the framework is all about how we deal with rate increases and that sort of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we think this is the appropriate way to go.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, again, broad support on the Committee.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: We’ll go to Nick Timiraos.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Hi, Nick Timiraos of the Wall Street Journal.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Chair Powell, you have said the test for liftoff is more stringent than the test for tapering.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: But if the near-term projections today are credible, more of your colleagues seem to think that rate liftoff, and not just a taper, may be closer at hand.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Does the Committee have a different opinion than you do about the threshold for liftoff that you’ve articulated?

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Or do they believe that either inflation or economic growth will necessitate a rate increase sooner than you do?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, so, again, substantial further progress toward our goals is the test for beginning the taper.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the taper takes some months in everyone’s figuring.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you’re going to be well away from satisfying the liftoff test when we begin the taper.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So in terms of the liftoff test, though, you know, it’s what we adopted last September.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s labor market conditions consistent with maximum employment.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And while we have interesting signs that, in many ways, the labor market’s very tight, we also have lots of slack in the labor market, and we think that those imbalances will sort themself out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Inflation at 2 percent and on track to achieve it, September 22, 2021 moderately higher inflation over 2 percent—you know, that really depends on the path of Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If inflation remains higher during the course of 2022, then we may already have met that test by the time we reach liftoff.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I just think, if you look at what people are writing down for year-end 2022 numbers, some people are writing down very low unemployment rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s only one indicator, but it suggests a very strong labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think they’re writing down in good faith what they see as meeting the test.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There’s a range of perspectives about where the economy will be, but—by the way, all but one participants have us lifting off during 2023.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s not really an unusually wide array of views about this.

speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: We’ll go to Jeanna Smialek.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Hey, Chair Powell—thank you for taking our questions.

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: Prior to recent media reports, were you aware of the kind of security buying and selling that Presidents Kaplan and Rosengren were participating in last year?

speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK
sentence: And I wonder if you thought those were appropriate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, no, I was not aware of the specifics of what they were doing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So let me just say a couple things about this subject.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We understand very well that the trust of the American people is essential for us to effectively carry out our mission.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s why I directed the Fed to begin a comprehensive review of the ethics rules around permissible financial holdings and activity by Fed officials.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So those rules are, in many respects, the same as those for government agencies, plus a number of things that apply specifically to us because of our business.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One of those is—sort of, three things I would point to in terms of specific restrictures.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: One is, ownership of certain assets is not allowed, and that’s bank securities and other things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Secondly, there are times when we’re not allowed to trade at all or to, you know, buy and sell financial assets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s the period immediately before and during an FOMC meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, third, there’s regular disclosure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So all of these—everyone’s, you know, ownership and activities are all disclosed on an annual basis.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, I would have had to go back and read people’s financial disclosures to know what their activities have been.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This has been our framework for a long time, and I guess you’d say it’s served us well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The other thing you would say—that it is now clearly seen as not adequate to the task of really sustaining the public’s trust in us.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We need to make changes, and we’re going to do that as a consequence of this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This will be a thoroughgoing and comprehensive review.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re going to gather all the facts and look at ways to further tighten our rules and standards.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Great.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: We’ll go to Steve Liesman.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: I want to follow up on Jeanna’s question, the issue of ownership of these stocks and trades.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Do you think it’s appropriate for Federal Reserve officials to be owning the same assets that the Federal Reserve is buying?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Is that one of the modifications that you’re looking at?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: And in that these—you said yourself, they’re clearly not seen as appropriate.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: In that the Fed’s code of conduct says Fed officials should avoid even the appearance of the, of conflict, do those trades, in fact—and holdings—violate the Fed’s code of conduct?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Finally, do you have a timeline as to when you might get—be done with your review?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Thank you, sir.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Don’t have a timeline yet; we can start with that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, well, let me address the muni question, since that’s in there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I personally owned municipal securities for many, many years, and in 2019, I froze that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Meaning I—they’re no—I’m holding all those securities, my wife and I, to maturity.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And munis were always thought to be a pretty safe place for a Fed person to invest because, as you know, the lore was that the Fed would never buy municipal securities.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it was not an uncommon thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so then comes the, you know, the COVID crisis, and I reversed that policy, and I did it without hesitating.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the reason was that the financial markets, including the municipal financial market, were very much on the verge of collapse.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it was time to go, and we did.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we also checked with the Office of Government Ethics and—who looked carefully at it and said that I didn’t have a conflict.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s one answer that I wanted to share with you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Secondly, you’re right, though, as—we’re going to be looking at all those things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t want to get ahead of the process here and speculate about particular outcomes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But this, again, comprehensive and deliberate process—we’re going to make changes.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I want to be able to look back on this years from now and know that we rose to meet this challenge and handled the situation well, and that what we did made a lot of sense and protected the public’s interest and the institution that we’re all a part of.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: I’m sorry, Chair Powell—I just want to follow up.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: You said I was right.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: When you said “right,” about that the Feds should not own—Federal Reserve officials should not own the same assets they’re buying?

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Is that— CHAIR POWELL.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: I think that’s a reasonable thing.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Yeah, and, of course, for the most part, we don’t.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: I mean, it was a real coincidence; I happened to pre-own these munis.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: They were bought many years ago, actually.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: And so we started buying munis as part of the Municipal September 22, 2021 Liquidity Facility.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: So it was really not a—it just was an unforeseen event.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: And I couldn’t sell Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL them, so what I did was, I just held them, checked with the ethics people, and went ahead.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: So, but as a general principle, yeah, that makes a lot of sense.

speaker: STEVE LIESMAN
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: We’ll go to Chris Rugaber.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: Thank you, Chair Powell.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: Wider question about jobs and the Fed’s schedule—the Fed’s policy framework that you laid out here.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: You and other Fed officials have often talked about expecting a job market pickup in September as more children return to school, freeing up more parents to work, COVID abating.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: You mentioned in the past the extra unemployment benefits expiring.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: There’s some real-time data suggesting that we may not be seeing much of a return of labor supply.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: So do you still expect to see that in the next couple of jobs reports?

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: And how would a relatively weak jobs report in September affect your plans?

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you’re right, we have a—really, I’ll call it a unique situation where, by many measures, the labor market is tight.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And 11 million job openings, very widespread reports from employers all over the economy saying it’s quite difficult to hire people, wages moving up, and that kind—so, quite a tight labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So our view, I think—widespread view a few months ago was that several things were coming together in the fall, including kids back to school, which would, you know, which would lighten caregiving duties, including the expiration of unemployment—extra unemployment benefits, and other things would come together to provide an increase in labor supply, and so we’d get out of this strange world where there’re lots of unemployed people and a high unemployment rate but a labor shortage.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so what happened was, Delta happened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you had this very sharp spike in Delta cases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think, so that affects—for example, when schools are open 60 percent of the time or when they’re always at a threat of being closed because of Delta, the Delta variant, you know, you might want to wait.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Rather than going ahead and taking a job and starting work only to have to quit it three weeks later, you’re going to wait until you’re confident of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So some of that may not have happened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Also, people didn’t, you know—as you know, hiring and spending in these face-to-face service industries, travel and leisure, it just kind of stopped during those months.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we—so that—really, the big shortfall in labor, in jobs, was largely in travel and leisure, and that’s because of—clearly because of Delta.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that all happened.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And so what we—we know things that didn’t happen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think there’s still—it may just be that it’s going to take more time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it still seems that, inexorably, people will—these are people who were largely working back in February of 2020.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They’ll get back to work when it’s time to do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It just may take a longer time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re right, though—it didn’t happen with any force in September, and a lot of that was Delta.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the—you asked also about the test for November.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think if the economy continues to progress broadly in line with expectations, then I think—and also the overall situation is appropriate for this, then I think we could easily move ahead at the next meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Or not, depending on whether we feel like that, those tests are met.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: Well, just a quick—if I could just quickly follow up, I mean, what, how much of that will depend on what kind of jobs report we get for September?

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: And, I mean, is it, you know, are you in a data-dependent phase here where you need to see certain numbers going ahead?

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: Or are we at a point where you’ve accumulated enough progress that— CHAIR POWELL.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: So it is, it’s accumulated progress.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: So, you know, for me, it wouldn’t take a knockout, great, super strong employment report.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: It would take a reasonably good employment report for me to feel like that test is met.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: And others on the Committee—many on the Committee feel that the test is already met.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: Others want to see more progress.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: And, you know, we’ll work it out as we go.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: But I would say that, in my own thinking, the test is all but met.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: So I don’t personally need to see a very strong employment report, but I’d like to see a good—a decent employment report.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: I mean, it’s not, it’s, again, it’s not to be confused with the test for liftoff, which is so much higher.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: Great.

speaker: CHRIS RUGABER
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Okay.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: We’ll go to Victoria Guida.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: Hi, Chair Powell.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: So I wanted to ask about the Vice Chair of Supervision position and just—I was wondering if you could speak about how you view that role and the extent to which you defer to that person on regulatory policy.

speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA
sentence: And then, just sort of a related question: As you know, Randy Quarles’s vice chairmanship ends next month, and I was wondering if he’s going to retain the supervisory portfolio until he’s replaced in that role.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So Dodd-Frank created this position, Vice Chair for Supervision, and it’s, there’s actually a specific assignment in the Dodd-Frank language, as I’m sure you know.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, effectively, what it means is that the Vice Chair for Supervision is charged with setting the regulatory agenda.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, it’s a specific grant of authority.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And in the 10 years, almost, that I’ve been at the Fed, that person has really done that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Dan Tarullo certainly did it, and Vice Chair Quarles did it as well.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I would, I think—I respect that authority.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I respect that that’s the person who will set the regulatory agenda going forward, and I would accept that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, furthermore, you know, it’s fully appropriate to look at—for a new person to come in and look at the current state of regulation and supervision and suggest appropriate changes, and I welcome that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of Vice Chair Quarles’s term, we’re not currently in that situation, and I actually don’t have any updates for you on that today.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ll keep you posted on that.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: We’ll go to Steve Matthews at Bloomberg.

speaker: STEVE MATTHEWS
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: STEVE MATTHEWS
sentence: Chair Powell, I wanted to ask about the inclusive monetary policy framework.

speaker: STEVE MATTHEWS
sentence: In particular, Bloomberg surveyed economists, and we found that they predict liftoff will happen when the U.S. unemployment rate is 3.8 percent but the Black unemployment rate is 6.1 percent.

speaker: STEVE MATTHEWS
sentence: And I’m wondering if a 6.1 percent unemployment rate for African Americans is consistent with full employment or whether it would need to be lower as part of your inclusive growth strategy.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Right, so the point of the broad and inclusive goal was not to target a particular unemployment rate for any particular group.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Really, we look at a broad range of—a very broad range of metrics when we think about what maximum employment is.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And one of the things we look at is unemployment rates and participation rates and wages for different demographic and age groups and that kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we will do all of that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think if you look back, what were we really thinking?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we all saw the benefits of a strong labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: If you look at the last two or three years of, before the pandemic hit, you saw—after a lot of long progress, you saw a really strong labor market.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you saw wages at the low end moving up faster than everywhere else—something that’s great to see.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also saw the lowest unemployment rates for minorities of various, you know, for African Americans, for example, and also participation rates.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We saw a really, really healthy set of dynamics.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, by the way, we also—there was no reason why it couldn’t continue.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There September 22, 2021 were no imbalances in the economy, and then along came the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We were not—there Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL was nothing in the economy that looked like a buildup of imbalances that could cause a recession.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I was very much thinking that the country would really benefit from a few more years of this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It would have been—so we’re all quite eager to get back to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also said we wouldn’t raise rates just in response to very low unemployment, in the absence of inflation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that was another aspect of it, because we saw that that really benefited labor market participants in a broad and inclusive way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s, of course, not the current situation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have significant slack in the economy and inflation well above target, not moderately above target.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, really, how we think about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It isn’t really just targeting the headline numbers, but it’s about taking all of those things into account in your thinking about what constitutes maximum employment.

speaker: STEVE MATTHEWS
sentence: Just to follow up, should there be a significant gap between Black unemployment and overall unemployment for structural reasons that are outside of the control of the Fed that other people should be doing something about?

speaker: STEVE MATTHEWS
sentence: Or should that be—should the gap be narrowed, if not down to zero?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, you really—I mean, first of all, ideally, there wouldn’t be any gap, of course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We would all love to see no such gap.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is a persistent gap, and it’s very hard to explain based on typical metrics.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s just, it’s quite troubling, but it really is—you know, we have, you know, famously broad and blunt tools.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think eliminating inequality and racial discrimination and racial disparities and that kind of thing is really something that fiscal policy and other policies—frankly, education policies and that kind of thing—are better at focusing on.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think we’ve identified the part that we can do, and we’ll do that part.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I’ve always been clear that it’s going to take policies broadly across society to work on these problems.

speaker: STEVE MATTHEWS
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Let’s go to Michael McKee.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: —a plan for dealing with a debt default that included prioritization, that included changes in bank regulations and possibly selling defaulted—or, nondefaulted Treasuries and buying those who are—that are.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Are any or all of those still on the table?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Do you think any of those would work?

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: And what would happen to the economy, in your view, should the debt ceiling not be raised?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, I missed the first few words, but I think I got your question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s just very important that the debt ceiling be raised in a timely fashion so that the United States can pay its bills when and as they come due.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s a critically important thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The failure to do that is something that could result in severe reactions, severe damage to the economy and to the financial markets.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it’s just not something that we could contemplate, that we should contemplate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m not going to comment on particular tactics or things like that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m just going to say that I think we can all agree that the United States shouldn’t default on any of its obligations—should pay them when and as due.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that, you know, no one should assume that the Fed or anyone else can protect the markets or the economy in the event of a failure—fully protect in the event of a failure to, you know, to make sure that we do pay those debts when they’re due.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: Good.

speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE
sentence: If I could follow up, have you discussed options with members of Congress?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, I don’t generally ever talk about the conversations I have with elected officials or other appointed officials.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, look, you can see that this is a major focus among those who have responsibility for it, and—including elected people.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Let’s go to Hannah Lang.

speaker: HANNAH LANG
sentence: Hi—thanks so much.

speaker: HANNAH LANG
sentence: Senator Warren sent you a letter last week urging the Fed to break up Wells Fargo, citing what she called “ungovernable behavior” from the bank.

speaker: HANNAH LANG
sentence: I’m just curious, under what circumstances would the Fed actually consider revoking a financial holding company’s license?

speaker: HANNAH LANG
sentence: And if the indiscretions at Wells Fargo, in your opinion, warrant such an action?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we’re, of course, very closely monitoring Wells Fargo’s efforts to fix its widespread and pervasive problems.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They represent a serious matter to us, and the firm is required to remediate them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we will take appropriate supervisory action if the firm fails to meet our expectation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We continue to hold the firm accountable for its deficiencies with an unprecedented asset cap that will stay in place until the firm has comprehensively fixed its problems.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And we’re not going to remove that asset cap until that’s done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So bottom line is, we’ll take strong supervisory action if a firm is engaging in unsafe and unsound practices or violating laws.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I can’t speak to our confidential supervisory assessments of any individual bank.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Now we’ll go to Michael Derby.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: Thank you for taking my question.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: You noted earlier in the press conference that you weren’t aware of the trading activity of the Boston and Dallas Fed Bank presidents.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: As you know, those, all 12 regional Fed Bank presidents just went through the renomination process earlier this year.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: And Governor Brainard described it as a rigorous process at the time.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: So I want to know, did anybody know—did anybody at the Board level know about the stock trading activity?

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: And, going forward, do you still have confidence in the Dallas and Boston Fed Bank presidents to do their job?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So these, I don’t need to tell you, we file, people file these reports annually.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think they were just quite recently filed for 2020.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I don’t have any reason to think people at the Board would have known about particular trading that’s going on.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: They will see that—there are people at the Fed who see the, you know, see the trading reports when they’re, you know, when they’re annually filed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, in terms of having confidence and that sort of thing, I think no one is happy, no one on the FOMC is happy to be in this situation, to be having these questions raised.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s something we take very, very seriously.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is an important moment for the Fed, and I’m determined that we will rise to the moment and handle it in ways that will stand up over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m very reluctant to get ahead of the process and speculate, though, about different things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, when we have things to announce, we’ll go ahead and do that, but that’s really what I have for today.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: One small follow-up.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: I mean, I know that you didn’t have the 2020 forms in hand, but you would have had past-year forms in hand.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: And at least in the case of, like, the Dallas disclosure forms, similar trading activity was shown in years past.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: So that, in theory, could have been something that came up in the renomination process.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s, yeah, that’s a good question.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, the five-year review that we do under this unusual provision of law where all of the Reserve Bank presidents are reviewed for reappointment at the same time every five years, that is really a broad review about their leadership of the institution, their performance on the FOMC, all of those things.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if there were a concern—a public concern or a private concern—about something that someone had done, we wouldn’t wait for the five-year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We wouldn’t wait that day if there were concerns.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re right, though, these—as I mentioned, we have had a framework for a long time, and it’s similar to what other government agencies have, only it’s a little stricter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it is that you can trade financial instruments, but not specific ones like bank debt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You can’t trade during the FOMC period and during the meeting—the blackout period and then during the meeting.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And then you disclose all this, and we have disclosed it for years.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So all of these things have been going—to the extent they’ve been going on, they’ve been a matter of public record.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know—but, nonetheless—so that—you know, it was seeming to work just okay.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And now you look at it, and you see this, and you think, “We need to do better.” And we will.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But you’re right, but it has not been part of the process.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, appropriately, I don’t think it should have been.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, I wouldn’t blame the people who conduct that review.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I really think, if someone had raised concerns or if we’d had concerns, then it would have been, but it wouldn’t have been part of that process.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It would have been raised instantly, rather than once every five years.

speaker: MICHAEL DERBY
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Let’s go to Jean Yung.

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: Thank you, Michelle.

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: Chair Powell, I wanted to ask about how the Fed would balance the two parts of its dual mandate if inflation stays elevated but we still have a labor shortage and participation remains lower than ideal.

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: Would you hold off on raising rates?

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: Or how would you think about that?

speaker: JEAN YUNG
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Well, let me say one thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You’re looking for conditions consistent with maximum employment to lift off, and those conditions can change over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you’re not necessarily bound by a particular level of the unemployment rate or the participation rate or anything else like that, which can change over time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But more to your point, really, we actually September 22, 2021 have a paragraph in our framework, and something like this has been there for a long time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s, I Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL think it’s paragraph six.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you’re talking about a situation in which the two goals are not complementary; they’re somehow in tension.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if we judge that’s effect—that is the case, what it says is, we take into account the employment shortfalls and inflation deviations and the potentially different time horizons over which employment and inflation are projected to return to levels judged consistent with the mandate.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, we used to call that the balanced-approach paragraph because it had those words.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it’s a very difficult situation for any central bank to be—pardon me—to be in a situation where the two goals are in tension.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that paragraph tries to address it by saying we would sort of weigh the equities between the two.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: How long will it take, and how big are the gaps, and that kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We don’t really think we’re in that—we’re sort of in that situation, I’d say, in a short-term way.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we think, we do expect that this is sort of—because of the COVID shock and the reopening and all that, you’re seeing this temporarily.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Great.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: We’ll go to Edward Lawrence.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Thank you, Michelle.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: Thank you, Mr. Chairman, for taking the question.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: So on corporate debt, what happened with Evergrande that we’ve been watching, could that be—is that a preview of what could happen with the amount of corporate debt that’s out there?

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: In the past you’ve said you’re watching the level of corporate debt.

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: So is, what’s your level of concern right now?

speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE
sentence: And would you consider the Evergrande Group issue sort of a warning signal?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: About the United States, no.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Corporate defaults are very low in the United States right now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Corporate leverage built up over the course of the long expansion that ended with the pandemic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We were very concerned in the last year or so.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We were concerned in September 22, 2021 the last year or so, and then I’d say very concerned at the beginning of the pandemic that, if Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL you’ve got a highly leveraged company and your revenue stops for an uncertain period, as things happened at the beginning of the crisis, we were very concerned that there would be a wave of defaults.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It didn’t happen, potentially—I mean, to a significant extent because of the CARES Act and the response that we undertook and all that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It was a, you know, a much stronger response than we’ve ever had.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think for whatever reason now, you have very, very low default rates now among corporate debt.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You know, the Evergrande situation seems very particular to China, which has very high debt for an emerging market economy, really the highest that any emerging market economy has had.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And the government has been working to get that under control.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: This is part of that effort.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The government put new strictures in place for highly leveraged companies.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And Evergrande is dealing with those strictures, and it’s something they’re managing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In terms of the implications for us, there isn’t, there’s not a lot of direct United States exposure.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The big Chinese banks are not tremendously exposed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, you would worry that it would affect global financial conditions through confidence channels and that kind of thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I wouldn’t draw a parallel to the United States corporate sector.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: We’ll go to Brian Cheung.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Hi, Chairman Powell.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Just wondering if you could give us an update on whether or not you’ve had conversations with the White House about a possible reappointment.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: And then whether or not you would like to be reappointed as this chatter kind of builds up.

speaker: BRIAN CHEUNG
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think the phrase goes: “I have nothing for you on that today.” Sorry.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I’m focused on doing my job— MICHELLE SMITH.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Let’s go to Greg Robb.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: —I’m focused on doing my job every day for the American people, and I don’t have any comment on that, Brian.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Sorry about that.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Let’s go to Greg Robb.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thanks for taking my question, Chair Powell.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: I was wondering if, in your discussion about the tapering that—you said that officials think it’s appropriate to end around the middle of the year—if there was any discussion about what happens to the balance sheet then.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: I’ve heard some Fed officials say that they wouldn’t shrink the balance sheet.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Was that discussed?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: And what’s your stance on shrinking the balance sheet?

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thanks.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So my thinking on this has been: Let’s get through the taper decision, and then let’s turn to those issues.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: There are a number of related issues that—you mentioned one, Greg, but, you know, and—which you need to start to think about, and we’ll do that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But I want to get, we want to get through this taper decision, and then turn to those issues, rather than start, you know, thinking about them now and having the minutes discuss them and get people thinking that we are, you know, focused on those issues, because we’re really not.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, we do have the experience of what we did last time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’ve watched other countries and what they’ve done.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So I think we’ll be able to get to sensible decisions fairly expeditiously when it’s time.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But it’s just not time yet, in my thinking.

speaker: GREG ROBB
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Let’s go to Scott Horsley.

speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY
sentence: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY
sentence: You talked a little bit about inflation expectations.

speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY
sentence: And there does seem to be something of a divide between market expectations and the views of professional economists—which are pretty much in line with the FOMC September 22, 2021 members—and laypeople’s expectations, at least as reflected in the recent New York Fed survey.

speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY
sentence: Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL How much weight do you put on laypeople’s expectations?

speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY
sentence: And what do you think accounts for that divide?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So within—let’s just take the household surveys generally.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The New York Fed survey, let me talk about that specifically, and this is from the New York Fed.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s only an eight-year-old survey, and it does seem as though the, they’re looking three years out.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And it seems like there’s a high correlation between three-year and one-year.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: For the most part, surveys are showing that households expect higher inflation in the near term but not in the longer term.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s also what expectations are showing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there are many, many different inflation measures, of course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And that’s why we have this thing called the CIE, which is the, it’s an index of—it’s market-based measures, it’s professional forecasters, and it’s household surveys.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And you just put them all—it’s not, you know, it doesn’t have a lot of grand theory about it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You put them all in, and you measure the change.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So you should be—and, also, you measure things like the dispersion and that sort of thing, so you can look at all that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, you know, it tells a story of inflation expectations moving up.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Many of the different measures will also show inflation expectations moving back up to where they were in, say, 2013, which was before the really—the drop in inflation expectations broadly happened in ’14 and ’15—around then.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So that’s not a troubling thing.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, you know, inflation expectations are terribly important.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We spend a lot of time watching them.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And if we did see them moving up in a troubling way and running persistently above levels that are really consistent with our mandate, then, you know, we would certainly react to that.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But we don’t really see that now.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We see more of a moderate increase that is—the September 22, 2021 first part of which is welcome.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And because, you know, inflation expectations had drifted down, Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL and it was good to see them get back up a bit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But, again, we watch carefully.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Let’s go to Heather Scott.

speaker: HEATHER SCOTT
sentence: Hi.

speaker: HEATHER SCOTT
sentence: Sorry, you caught me off guard.

speaker: HEATHER SCOTT
sentence: Thank you, Chair Powell, for taking my question.

speaker: HEATHER SCOTT
sentence: I really appreciate it.

speaker: HEATHER SCOTT
sentence: Again, on the taper timing.

speaker: HEATHER SCOTT
sentence: You say it’s going to last to the middle of next year.

speaker: HEATHER SCOTT
sentence: But with your concerns about the potential for upside risks to inflation, would you think you might need to have liftoff happen before you finish the tapering?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s not my expectation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Of course, we can always—we haven’t decided to taper yet, and we haven’t decided the pace yet.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, you know, it’s not my expectation that we would have to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We can certainly speed up or slow down the taper if we—if it becomes appropriate, though.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Absolutely.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: In fact, back in ’13, when we tapered, we always said we weren’t on a preset course.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think this will be a shorter period.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The economy’s much farther along than it was when we tapered in 2013.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So it makes sense to allow the runoff to happen.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a very gradual taper.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It will be when we agree on it.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And, but we certainly have the freedom to either speed it up or slow it down if that becomes appropriate.

speaker: HEATHER SCOTT
sentence: But you wouldn’t expect rate liftoff to happen until you’re finished with that process?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: You wouldn’t, no, because, you know, when you’re—as long as you’re buying assets, you’re adding accommodation, and it wouldn’t make any sense to, you know, then lift off.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I mean, what you would do is, you’d speed up the taper, I think, if that were the situation you’re in.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Not—we don’t expect to be in that situation, but I do think it would be wiser at that point to go ahead and speed up the taper, just because the two are then working in the same direction.

speaker: HEATHER SCOTT
sentence: All right, thank you.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Okay, for the last question, we’ll go to Jeff Cox.

speaker: JEFF COX
sentence: Thank you, Mr. Chairman, for taking the question.

speaker: JEFF COX
sentence: I just wanted to check in with you to see if you have an update at all on the efforts from the Fed to develop a central bank digital currency.

speaker: JEFF COX
sentence: I believe that the report was supposed to come this summer, and indications that it’s going to come this month.

speaker: JEFF COX
sentence: But the drumbeat seems to be kind of getting louder to see where the Fed’s heading on this, and just wondering if you can provide some update there.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Sure, I’d be glad to.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So we think it’s really important that the central bank maintain a stable currency and payment system for the public’s benefit.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: That’s one of our jobs.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We also live in a time of transformational innovation around digital payments, and we need to make sure that the Fed is able to continue to deliver to the public a stable and trustworthy currency and payment system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So there’s extensive private innovation, a lot of which is taking place outside the regulatory perimeter.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And innovation is fantastic.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Our economy runs on innovation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: But where the public’s money is concerned, we need to make sure that appropriate regulatory protections are in place, and today they really are not in some cases.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So with that in mind and with the creation of myriad private currencies and currency-like products, we’re working proactively to evaluate whether to issue a CBDC and, if so, in what form.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We have two broad workstreams, one of which is really technology, both at the Board and in the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston’s work with MIT—the other of which is to identify, scope out, deal with, analyze the various public policy issues.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: As you mentioned, we do intend to publish a discussion paper soon that will be the basis for a period of public engagement—engagement with many different groups, including elected officials, around these issues.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We September 22, 2021 think it’s our obligation to do the work, both on technology and public policy, to form a basis for Chair Powell’s Press Conference FINAL making an informed decision.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: The ultimate test we’ll apply when assessing a central bank digital currency and other digital innovations is: Are there clear and tangible benefits that outweigh any costs and risks?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We’re also, as you know, investing heavily right now in building a new settlement system for instant payments in the U.S. It’ll be the first such major expansion of our core payment system since the 1970s.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We found the case for this quite compelling—for consumers, businesses, and just ensuring that all financial institutions have access to that payment system.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: So, bottom line, we haven’t made a decision about the CBDC, but we will be issuing a discussion paper soon in order to form the basis of this public interaction that we’ll have.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thank you very much.

speaker: JEFF COX
sentence: If I could have a quick—could I get a quick follow on that?

speaker: JEFF COX
sentence: Thank you.

speaker: JEFF COX
sentence: I was just wondering if—okay—are you concerned at all with kind of falling behind in the global race for digital currencies?

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think it’s important that we get to a place where we can make an informed decision about this and do so expeditiously.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I don’t think we’re behind.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: I think it’s more important to do this right than to do it fast.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We are the world’s reserve currency.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think we’re in a good place to make that analysis and make that decision—by the way, which will be a governmentwide decision.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We would do this, we would have to have a meeting of the minds with the Administration and also probably with Congress.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: We would really like to have broad support for this.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: It’s a very important innovation.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: And I think we would need that to go ahead, and that’s the process we’re engaged in.

speaker: CHAIR POWELL
sentence: Thanks very much.

speaker: MICHELLE SMITH
sentence: Thank you.
